# godelizer
Compute the Godel number of any valid Godelian formula! (Or of any invalid one. It doesn't judge!)

The numbering system used here is the one described in Kurt Godel's 1930 paper,
"On Formally Undecidable Propositions of Principia Mathematica and Related Systems."

Arithmetize your formulae and determine their set membership among the provables,
unless you can't!

NOTE: This will just give you the number. Proving set membership is left as an exercise
for the reader.

A sample run is shown below:
```
% python3 godelizer.py 
Welcome to Godelizer!
This program will convert P formulae into Godel numbers.
Syntax: 
0 - Nought
f - Successor
~ - Not 
| - Disjunction
^ - Universal quantifier
() - Brackets
a - Variables of the first type begin with lower case letter
A - Variables of the second type begin with upper case letter
AA - Variables of the third type are completely upper case
Enter a P formula: 0
The arithmetic formula to generate the Godel number is: 2**(1)
The Godel number of the formula is: 2
Enter a P formula: f0
The arithmetic formula to generate the Godel number is: 2**(3)*3**(1)
The Godel number of the formula is: 24
Enter a P formula: ff0
The arithmetic formula to generate the Godel number is: 2**(3)*3**(3)*5**(1)
The Godel number of the formula is: 1080
Enter a P formula: fff0
The arithmetic formula to generate the Godel number is: 2**(3)*3**(3)*5**(3)*7**(1)
The Godel number of the formula is: 189000
Enter a P formula: a|b|~c
WARNING: Ignoring character ~
The arithmetic formula to generate the Godel number is: 2**(17**1)*3**(7)*5**(19**1)*7**(7)*11**(23**1)
The Godel number of the formula is: 4031872875979626423470446027753177500000000000000000
Enter a P formula: x^A(x)
The arithmetic formula to generate the Godel number is: 2**(17**1)*3**(9)*5**(17**3)*7**(11)*11**(17**1)*13**(13)
The Godel number of the formula is: 
```
